{{about|the organization|other uses|High Tech High (disambiguation)}} {{multiple issues| {{advert|date=July 2014}} {{notability|Companies|date=July 2014}} }}
{{infobox school | name=High Tech High | type=Charter schools | location=California | founded=2000 | website={{URL|https://www.hightechhigh.org/}} | ratio=19 to 1<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.niche.com/k12/high-tech-high-school-san-diego-ca/#about| publisher=Niche| title=High Tech High School|access-date=March 29, 2018}}</ref> | district=[[San Diego Unified School District]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-high-schools/california/districts/san-diego-unified-school-district/high-tech-high-3217|publisher=US News|title=Overview|access-date=March 29, 2018}}</ref> }}
'''High Tech High''' is a [[San Diego, California]]-based school-development organization that includes a network of [[charter schools]], a teacher certification program, and a [[graduate school]] of education.<ref name='High Tech High'>{{cite web|url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/ |title=About High Tech High |accessdate=2011-05-07 |year=2010 |work=High Tech High web site |publisher=High Tech High Foundation |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yVuLBiQc?url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/ |archivedate=2011-05-07 |quote=High Tech High began in 2000 as a single charter high school launched by a coalition of San Diego business leaders and educators. It has evolved into an integrated network of schools spanning grades K-12, housing a comprehensive teacher certification program and a new, innovative Graduate School of Education. |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Students are admitted to the public elementary, middle, and high schools through a zip-code based lottery system in an effort to admit a demographically-diverse representative sample of San Diego County.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kahlenberg|first1=Richard D.|last2=Potter|first2=Halley|title=A Smarter Charter: Finding What Works for Charter Schools and Public Education|date=September 15, 2014|publisher=Teachers College Press|location=New York|isbn=0807755796|page=186}}</ref>
==History==
In 1996, forty members of San Diego’s civic and high-tech industry<ref name="Questions for Larry Rosenstock">{{cite news|last1=Federis|first1=Marnette|title=Questions for Larry Rosenstock|url=http://voiceofsandiego.org/2006/09/02/questions-for-larry-rosenstock/|accessdate=8 August 2014|agency=Voice of San Diego|publisher=Voice of San Diego|date=September 2, 2006}}</ref> assembled to discuss how to engage and prepare more young people for the high-tech industry. Called upon by the San Diego Economic Development Corporation and Business Roundtable, these members met regularly for the next two years to discuss how to engage and prepare local students for high-tech careers.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bellanca|first1=James A.|title=The focus factor : 8 essential twenty-first century thinking skills for deeper student learning|date=2013|publisher=Teachers College Press|location=New York, NY|isbn=080775448X}}</ref> One of these members included [[Gary E. Jacobs]], former director of education programs at Qualcomm.<ref name="Questions for Larry Rosenstock"/>
The original "High Tech High School" is now known as The [[Gary and Jerri-Ann Jacobs High Tech High]].
In 2000, the [[San Diego Unified School District]] approved the first charter and construction began in a former U.S. Navy training center in the Point Loma district, now known as Liberty Station, near the San Diego airport. The grouping of High Tech High schools in this area is known as [[High Tech High Village]]. With a grant from the [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]], High Tech High opened with 200 students in the 9th and 10th grades in September. In 2003, the first graduating class graduated with 50 students. In 2006, the Statewide Benefit Charter was approved. In 2007, High Tech High Digital Commons launched. In 2009, the statewide Benefit Charter was expanded to K-12.{{cn|date=March 2018}}
In 2010, it had approximately 3,500 students in high, middle, and elementary schools. The HTH website states that in 2010, 100% of high school graduates were accepted to colleges, of which 80% were to four-year institutions.<ref>[http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/ School website, retrieved online 2011-04-21] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5yVuLBiQc?url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/ |date=2011-05-07 }}</ref> As of 2008, 99% percent of graduates had entered college.<ref>[http://www.edutopia.org/collaboration-age-technology-high-tech ''Edutopia'' article, retrieved online 2011-04-21]</ref> As of 2015, 98% of students attended college after graduation, with around 75% attending 4-year schools. According to statistics from that year, students of HTH scored higher than others within their demographic groups elsewhere in the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ewa.org/blog-educated-reporter/can-kicking-down-conventions-close-achievement-gap|publisher=Education Writers Association|title=Can Kicking Down Conventions Close the Achievement Gap?| author=Shelby Webb| date=December 9, 2015|access-date=March 29, 2018}</ref>
==Program design principles== The High Tech High program and curriculum evolved from the work of [[Larry Rosenstock]] and colleagues in the New Urban High School Project, an initiative of the U.S. Department of Education’s Office of Vocational and Adult Education.<ref>[http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/design-principles.php School website, retrieved online 2011-04-21]</ref> The focus was on inner-city high schools using school-to-work strategies, including internships and other forms of field work, as a leverage for whole-school change. The findings of the NUHS were summarized in guides centered on six design principles. The school is virtually textbook-free.<ref>[http://www.edutopia.org/collaboration-age-technology-high-tech "Real World, San Diego: Hands-On Learning at High Tech High" article by Grace Rubenstein in Edutopia, 2008-12-03, retrieved online 2011-04-28]</ref> HTH is structured around four design principles, including three from NUHS and one developed by HTH:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kqed.org/mindshift/50443/whats-so-different-about-high-tech-high-anyway|publisher=Mind/Shift|title=What’s So Different About Hight Tech High Anyway?| author=Katrina Schwartz| date=February 6, 2018|access-date=March 29, 2018}}</ref> * personalization * adult world connection * common intellectual mission * teacher as designer
These principles determined the [[school organizational models|schools' organization]], including their small size, the openness of the facilities, personalization, emphasis on integrated and project-based learning, and display and exhibitions of student work. All students are required to complete internships in the community. HTH director Ben Daley described the school's approach: "We are teaching students to think deeply about content and then do something with their knowledge, not just race through a textbook.”<ref>[http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/San-Diego-Magazine/July-2006/Great-Schools/ Great Schools article by Marcia Manna in ''San Diego Magazine'', 2006-07, retrieved online 2011-04-28]</ref> According to Rosenstock, who became a CEO of HTH, a slogan at High Tech High is: “You can play video games at HTH, but only if you make them here.”<ref>[http://www.bigpicture.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/020501-technos-quarterly.pdf Pearlman: '' TECHNOS'', Vol. 11, No. 1 • Spring 2002, retrieved online 2011-04-21]</ref>
==Governance and funding== The schools operate within the [[San Diego Unified School District]] but the High Tech High organization is governed by three independent boards of directors:<ref>[http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/governance.php School website, retrieved online 2011-03-21]</ref> * The High Tech High Board operates as a public agency and has governance and fiduciary level control over all HTH schools. * HTH Learning is a private nonprofit that oversees the facilities that house the schools of High Tech High. It is also responsible for the adult learning programs, including the teacher certification program, and the related residencies and institutes. * The High Tech High Foundation is a private nonprofit responsible for securing the philanthropic support needed to develop High Tech High schools.
The schools are publicly funded although they have received grants from private companies and organizations. The [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]] contributed $17 million between 2000 and 2006.<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/06_26/b3990001.htm "Bill Gates Gets Schooled", Business Week article, 2006-06-26, retrieved online 2011-04-28]</ref>
==Schools== * [[Explorer Elementary Charter School]] * High Tech Elementary (Point Loma High Tech Village Campus, Opened 2015) * High Tech Elementary Chula Vista * High Tech Elementary North County * High Tech Middle Chula Vista * [[High Tech Middle]] * [[High Tech Middle Media Arts]] * High Tech Middle North County * The [[Gary and Jerri-Ann Jacobs High Tech High]] * [[High Tech High International]] * [[High Tech High Media Arts]] * High Tech High Mesa * High Tech High Chula Vista * High Tech High North County
Formerly there was also a High Tech High Bayshore, in Redwood City.
==Student learning==
===Notable projects===
'''San Diego Bay Study'''
Since 2003, Dr. Jay Vavra and the juniors of [[Gary and Jerri-Ann Jacobs High Tech High]] have started and maintained the [http://www.sdbayguide.com/ San Diego Bay Study],<ref>{{cite news|last1=McLaughlin|first1=Evan|title=A Sea Change from Chalkboards and Textbooks: Questions for Jay Vavra|url=http://voiceofsandiego.org/2006/06/17/a-sea-change-from-chalkboards-and-textbooks-questions-for-jay-vavra/?action=rpx_token|accessdate=17 August 2014|agency=Voice of San Diego|date=17 June 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=The Students of High Tech High, San Diego|title=San Diego Bay Study|url=http://www.sdbayguide.com/|website=San Diego Bay Study|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> producing four books on what students deemed “pressing environmental priorities.”<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Students of High Tech High, San Diego |title=San Diego Bay Study (Overview) |url=http://www.sdbayguide.com/overview.html |website=San Diego Bay Study |accessdate=17 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819090458/http://www.sdbayguide.com/overview.html |archivedate=19 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> Conservationist [[Jane Goodall]] wrote the forward to the initial ''The Two Sides of Sides of the Bay Channel: A Field Guide''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Students of High Tech High, San Diego |title=San Diego Bay Study (Books) |url=http://www.sdbayguide.com/books.html |website=San Diego Bay Study |accessdate=17 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819085942/http://www.sdbayguide.com/books.html |archivedate=19 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> and the second study, ''Perspectives from the San Diego Bay: A Field Guide'' in which students used John Steinbeck’s [[The Log from the Sea of Cortez]] as the model for a more humanitarian guide.
'''The Blood Bank Project'''
In 2009, a team of twelfth-graders, led by art teacher Jeff Robin and biology/multimedia teacher Blair Hatch, collaborated with the [http://www.sandiegobloodbank.org/ San Diego Blood Bank] to raise awareness for the need to donate blood.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Blood Bank Project: Team Teaching |url=http://bie.org/object/video/the_blood_bank_project_team_teaching|website=Buck Institute for Education|publisher=Buck Institute for Education|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> Students researched several blood-related topics, ranging from leukemia to the AIDS epidemic to the depiction of blood in films to the role of blood in various religions.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Price|first1=David|title=Open: how we'll work, live and learn in the future|date=10 November 2013|publisher=Crux|location=England|isbn=1909979015|page=177}}</ref> In pairs, students created paintings large piece of wood with cut-outs for a student-created informational video. The products were displayed at the JETT Art Gallery in San Diego.
'''The End of the World Project (and co-design)'''
During the fall of 2012, sixth-graders at High Tech Middle co-designed a project with teachers Bobby Shaddox and Allie Wong. Building on the work of democratic educator [[James Beane]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Apple|first1=Michael|last2=Beane|first2=James|title=Democratic Schools, Second Edition: Lessons in Powerful Education|date=30 January 2007|publisher=Heinemann|location=Portsmouth, NH|isbn=0325010757}}</ref> Shaddox and Wong asked students to generate questions they had about themselves and the world around them. They categorized these questions and then determined that many questions fell under the broader theme of “The End of the World.” Teachers then pitched the idea of creating a magazine and multimedia exhibition informing the public of the plausibility of the various (and rumored) ways in which the world might be brought to an end. In pairs, students researched topics ranging from global warming to deforestation to the Mayan prophecies. Students included interviews from local experts in their articles. Because teachers wanted to establish a democratic working environment, student input on the process was ongoing. Students were asked to tune project components, utilize peer feedback, and meet regularly as a whole-class community to make decisions about the process and product.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shaddox|first1=Bobby|title=Co-design: A Democratic Approach to Project-Based Learning|date=6 June 2013|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|isbn=1490380159|url=http://bobbyshaddoxtl.weebly.com/}}</ref>
'''The Raptors for Rodents Project'''
In the fall of 2014, fifth-graders at High Tech Elementary Chula Vista were visited regularly by the field mice that populated the open landscape surrounding the building. Students led by teacher Jeff Govoni researched the local predators of these rodents to determine which might be the safest and most effective way to reduce the population. Students determined that owls would have the greatest impact and so they then, in teams, investigated and created prototypes for owl boxes. In order to raise funding to build life-size versions, students wrote persuasive letters and created multimedia presentations. Upon funding, students built the nests and did, in fact, reduce the population of field mice in their school.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Govoni |first1=Jeff |title=Raptors for Rodents |journal=UnBoxed: A Journal of Adult Learning in Schools |date=Spring 2014 |issue=11 |url=https://www.hightechhigh.org/unboxed/issue11/cards/8.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150124064029/http://www.hightechhigh.org/unboxed/issue11/cards/8.php |archivedate=2015-01-24 |df= }}</ref>
===Extracurriculars===
'''[[The Holy Cows]]'''
[[The Holy Cows]] are a robotics team co-founded by High Tech High engineering teacher David Berggren and his father, Bill Berggren in 2004. The team runs like a business, with students fulfilling roles including student directors, managers, and supervisors of various departments. Students are mentored by local engineering experts, including Holy Cows alumnus Jon Jock of Seabotix,<ref name="kpbs.org">{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Dwane|title=High Tech High Team Headed to Robotics Championship|url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2013/apr/04/high-tech-high-team-headed-robotics-championship/|accessdate=19 August 2014|agency=KPBS San Diego Public Radio & TV: News, Arts & Culture|publisher=KPBS San Diego Public Radio & TV: News, Arts & Culture|date=5 April 2013}}</ref> to accrue skills through the building of robots. In alignment with the High Tech High mission, they also learn to manage projects as a team.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bogo|first1=Jennifer|title=FIRST Robotics 2010 Championship Photo Gallery|url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/technology/engineering/robots/first-robotics-2010-championship-photo-gallery-holy-cows#slide-6|website=Popular Mechanics|publisher=Popular Mechanics|accessdate=19 August 2014}}</ref> [[The Holy Cows]] have traveled to the First Robotics World Championship eight times, as of 2013<ref name="kpbs.org"/> and won the top prize, the Chairman’s Award, in 2013.<ref name="SD school world robotics champion">{{cite news|last1=Magee|first1=Maureen|title=SD school world robotics champion|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2013/may/01/sd-school-wins-world-robotics-competition/|accessdate=19 August 2014|agency=U-T San Diego|publisher=U-T San Diego|date=1 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Fox 5 San Diego|title=Nathan Fletcher speaks about High Tech High’s robotics championship |url=http://fox5sandiego.com/2013/05/10/nathan-fletcher-speaks-about-high-tech-highs-robotics-championship/#axzz37CsWKrlN|accessdate=19 August 2014|agency=Fox 5 San Diego|publisher=Fox 5 San Diego|date=10 May 2013}}</ref> The team also mentors other robotics teams and offers workshops.<ref name="SD school world robotics champion"/> In 2014, the [[Holy Cows]] and their robot were one of five robotics teams that opened the [[Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Staff and contribution|title=HTH Point Loma gets spotlight in Macy’s Parade for robotics prowess |url=http://www.sdnews.com/view/full_story/24218229/article-HTH-Point-Loma-gets-spotlight-in-Macy-s-Parade-for-robotics-prowess?instance=update1|accessdate=19 August 2014|agency=San Diego Community Newspaper Group}}</ref>
==Adult learning== While HTH distilled its first three learning principles from The Urban School Project, it added a fourth: "Teacher as Designer" and employs a rigorous hiring process. It also stated a commitment to educating educators.<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Resource Center on Charter School Finance & Governance|title=Implementing an In-House Approach to Teacher Training and Professional Development|url=https://www.usc.edu/dept/education/cegov/focus/charter-schools/publications/other/An_In-House_Approach_to_Teacher_Training_HighTechHigh.pdf|website=University of Southern California Center on Educational Governance|publisher=National Resource Center on Charter School Finance & Governance|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
===Teacher hiring and support===
After an initial pre-screening of application materials, prospective teachers are invited to attend a day-long hiring “Bonanza” on a High Tech High school. In addition to touring the schools and mingling with prospective co-workers, they implement an hour-long lesson to class of students. Students are integral to the hiring process at High Tech High. Not only do they offer their feedback on the demonstration lesson, but they are invited to read and engage in a discussion with applicants on a sensitive, but relevant, topic as current High Tech High educators observe.<ref name="High Tech's Hiring 'Bonanza'">{{cite news|last1=Alpert|first1=Emily|title=High Tech's Hiring 'Bonanza'|url=http://voiceofsandiego.org/2009/02/20/high-techs-hiring-bonanza/|accessdate=21 August 2014|agency=Voice of San Diego|publisher=Voice of San Diego}}</ref> Hiring is competitive, and many vie for spots that open annually. Although High Tech High is publicly funded, it operates under its own board of directors, and thus can create its own hiring process. Directors of the school’s campuses take teacher and student feedback into account, along with their current school needs, when offering candidates a position.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shields|first1=Regis Anne|last2=Ireland|first2=Nicole|last3=City|first3=Elizabeth|last4=Derderian|first4=Julie|last5=Miles|first5=Karen Hawley|title=Case Studies of Leading Edge Small Urban High Schools|url=http://www.erstrategies.org/cms/files/1010-high-tech-high-school.pdf|website=Education Resource Strategies|publisher=Education Resource Strategies|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> High Tech High teachers are contracted for one year and do not receive tenure, nor do they have a teacher’s union.<ref name="High Tech's Hiring 'Bonanza'"/>
===Teacher credentialing=== High Tech High is authorized by the [[California Commission on Teacher Credentialing]] to offer preliminary and professional credentials. It offers two programs: The Intern Program for preliminary teaching credentials and the two-year Induction Program for teachers with preliminary teaching credentials.
In order to invite qualified applicants who do not yet hold teaching credential to work with High Tech High, the organization developed its own credential program in 2004, becoming the state’s first approved charter-management organization (CMO) to do so.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robelen|first1=Erik W.|title=Learning Where They Teach|url=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2007/07/18/43hightech.h26.html|website=Education Week|publisher=Education Week|accessdate=30 July 2014}}</ref> Educators who wish to work with High Tech High may earn a teaching credential through the Teacher Intern Program. Those who possess (at a minimum) B.A. or B.S. upon hiring and demonstrate subject-matter competence may apply for employment under the condition that they will enroll concurrently in a credential and induction program.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Husbands|first1=Jennifer|title=Alternative Routes to Teacher Certification|journal=UnBoxed: A Journal of Adult Learning in Schools|date=Spring 2008|issue=1|url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/unboxed/issue1/alternative_certification/|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> The credential program is accredited by the California Commission on Teacher Credentialing,<ref>{{cite web|title=Educator Training|url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/educator_training.php|website=High Tech High website|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> is recognized for resisting the theoretical approach many credential programs are criticized for,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barnett|first1=Barry|title=Teaching Quality and the Question of Preparation|url=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2005/10/19/08berry.h25.html|website=Education Week|publisher=Education Week|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> and adopting a clinical approach, akin to a medical residency. It authorizes Single-Subject, Multiple Subjects and Education Specialist credentials for staff and non-HTH teachers. Most interns teach full-time while earning their credentials, earning a regular salary and benefits. Graduates of the program present a portfolio of their work, demonstrating that they have met the qualifications to be licensed as a teacher in the state of California.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wurdinger|first1=Scott D.|title=Time for Action: Stop Teaching to the Test and Start Teaching Skills|date=9 December 2011|publisher=R&L Education|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=978-1610486606|page=91}}</ref>
In 2004, High Tech High was authorized to move teachers from preliminary to clear credential through an induction (BTSA) program.<ref>{{cite news|title=High Tech High? San Diego's charter organization now offers a grad school|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20080824/news_lz1ed24bottom.html|accessdate=12 August 2014|publisher=San Diego Union-Tribune|date=24 August 2008}}</ref> The High Tech High Teacher Induction (BTSA) program began in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=High Tech High website|url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/about/induction.php|website=High Tech High|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref>
===Graduate School of Education=== The Graduate School of Education opened in September 2007, offering Master of Education Degrees (M.Ed) in Teacher Leadership and School Leadership to educators in and outside of the network of High Tech High schools.<ref>{{cite web|title=High Tech High Graduate School of Education|url=http://www.calcharters.org/2011/09/high-tech-high-graduate-school-of-education.html|website=California Charter Schools Association|publisher=California Charter Schools Association|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> In 2012, the school was granted candidacy for accreditation by WASC (Western Association of Schools and Colleges),<ref>{{cite web|title=Statement of Accreditation Status High Tech High Graduate School of Education|url=http://www.wascsenior.org/institutions/high-tech-high-graduate-school-education|website=WASC Senior College and University Commission|publisher=WASC Senior College and University Commission|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> and the school became fully accredited in 2016. The school’s president, Dr. Rob Riordan, formerly a leader of the teaching practicum at the Harvard Graduate School of Education<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rubenstein|first1=Grace|title=What's Not on the Test: How to Turn Assessment into Learning A Q&A with High Tech High teaching guru Rob Riordan.|url=http://www.edutopia.org/high-tech-high-assessment|website=Edutopia|publisher=Edutopia|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> worked with school founder (and GSE Dean, with a total compensation of $420,202 reported in the school's 2015 990 federal tax form)<ref>http://990finder.foundationcenter.org/990results.aspx?990_type=&fn=high+tech+high&st=&zp=&ei=&fy=&action=Search</ref> [[Larry Rosenstock]] on the New Urban High School Project and as High Tech High’s “Emperor of Rigor".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Price|first1=David|title=OPEN: How we'll work, live and learn in the future|date=10 November 2013|publisher=Crux Publishing|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1909979015|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F3j4AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT126&lpg=PT126&dq=rob+riordan+emperor+of+rigor&source=bl&ots=XTTZIo1REb&sig=8v9O6RIrXVwBaCofrsHpVzlZoAs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fb3iU9OSB8nvoASpm4GQBg&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=rob%20riordan%20emperor%20of%20rigor&f=false}}</ref> According to administrative dean Allison Ohle, the school emphasizes “the value of collaboration and real-life experiences”.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kopietz|first1=Courtni|last2=Harrington|first2=Samantha|last3=Lodaya|first3=Hetali|title=High Tech High philosophy encourages project-based learning|url=http://stemwire.org/2013/08/02/high-tech-high-philosophy-encourages-project-based-learning/|website=STEMwire|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> Like the credential program, the graduate school emphasizes a clinical and practical approach while also exploring educational theory. Students are required to complete an “action research” project during the second year of the program, in which they explore a learning problem or wondering within their own school site. The results are published in the required thesis.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wagner|first1=Tony|last2=Compton|first2=Robert A.|title=Creating innovators: the making of young people who will change the world|date=17 April 2012|publisher=Scribner|location=New York|isbn=145161151X|page=192}}</ref> Students develop skills to work collaboratively and design courses in which their own students “construct new knowledge” and “pursue their passions.”<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wagner|first1=Tony|last2=Compton|first2=Robert A.|title=Creating innovators: the making of young people who will change the world|date=17 April 2012|publisher=Scribner|location=New York|isbn=1451611498|pages=192–3}}</ref> The Graduate School of Education hosts residencies, institutes, and workshops and its students participate in the High Tech High Summer Institute.<ref>{{cite web|title=HTH Graduate School of Education|url=http://gse.hightechhigh.org/|website=HTH Graduate School of Education|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref>
'''Leading Schools Program'''<br /> The Leading Schools Program (LSP) is a one-year certificate program that engages international and national teams of educators in online discussions and onsite residencies at High Tech High schools. Participants collaborate with, and are mentored by, current High Tech High educators as they create and carry out a leadership project that “addresses and authentic need or issue at their home schools."<ref>{{cite web|title=HTH GSE: Leading Schools Program |url=http://gse.hightechhigh.org/leading_schools.php |website=HTH GSE: Leading Schools Program |accessdate=12 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812211357/http://gse.hightechhigh.org/leading_schools.php |archivedate=12 August 2014 |df= }}</ref>
===UnBoxed: Journal and Speaker Series===
UnBoxed is a peer-reviewed journal published twice annually by the High Tech High Graduate School of Education.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Krauss|first1=Jane I.|last2=Boss|first2=Suzanne K.|title=Thinking Through Project-Based Learning: Guiding Deeper Inquiry|date=8 March 2013|publisher=Corwin|location=Newbury Park, CA|isbn=978-1452202563|page=185|edition=1}}</ref> Articles feature reflections on practice, project descriptions, and remarks on current policy.<ref>{{cite web|title=UnBoxed: About Us|url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/unboxed/about.php|website=UnBoxed: About Us|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> Contributors have included current faculty and graduate school students, as well as educators and researchers from various national and international institutions.
As part of the Education UnBoxed Speaker Series, educators such as co-founder of [[The Civil Rights Project]], [[Gary Orfield]], Professor [[James Gee]], and co-author of ''Disrupting Class: How Disruptive Education Will Change the Way the World Learns'', Michael Horn, have spoken on campus<ref>{{cite web|title=UnBoxed: online[ Past Events ]|url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/unboxed/previousEvents.php|website=UnBoxed: online[ Past Events ]|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> and through interactive, online platforms such as Elluminate. In addition, the graduate school hosts monthly “Collegial Conversations” in which educators are invited to discuss student work, methods of assessment, and developing projects using conversation protocols.<ref>{{cite web|title=UnBoxed: online[ Events ]|url=http://www.hightechhigh.org/unboxed/events.php|website=UnBoxed: online[ Events ]}}</ref>

An '''independent scholar''' is anyone who conducts scholarly research outside [[universities]] and traditional [[academia]].
In the US, a [[professional association]] exists for independent scholars: this association is the [[National Coalition of Independent Scholars]]. In Canada, the equivalent professional association is the Canadian Academy of Independent Scholars (in association with [[Simon Fraser University]]). Similar organizations exist around the world. Membership in a professional association generally entails a degree of post-secondary education and established research.
==See also== * [[Autodidacticism]] * [[Citizen science]] * [[List of notable autodidacts]] * [[Independent scientist]] * [[Independent study]] * [[Outsider art]] * [[Unschooling]]

Tarcher|location=New York City|isbn=0-87477-957-X}}

{{Infobox organization | name = Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue Group | native_name = | named_after = | image = LivingRoomDialogueLogo.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date|1992|7}} | founder = Adham Salem, Nahida Salem, Libby Traubman, Len Traubman | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = | status = | purpose = Non-Violent Conflict Resolution and Dialogue | headquarters = | location = [[San Mateo, California]] | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://traubman.igc.org/dg-prog.htm|Official website}} }}
The '''Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue Group''' is a [[Nonviolent Communication|non-violent]] [[conflict resolution]] group established in 1992 in [[San Mateo, California]]. Its first meeting was held in a local neighborhood residence. As of January 2018, the group remained active and continued to meet monthly in members' homes.<ref name="JP20Y">Jewish-Palestinian dialogue group still going strong after 20 years – by alix wall, j. correspondent In j., the Jewish news weekly of Northern California – Thursday, December 13, 2012 – [http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/67286/jewish-palestinian-dialogue-group-still-going-strong-after-20-years]</ref> The one-to-one, face-to-face method of [[conflict resolution]], modeled by this dialogue group, was increasingly looked to globally by educators, researchers, journalists, activists, trainers, and strategists including the [[U.S. Department of State]], which distributes the dialogue group's instructive films in Africa.<ref name="auto">{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/113065533|title=DIALOGUE IN NIGERIA: Muslims & Christians Creating Their Future (65 min)|work=Vimeo}}</ref>
Members of the group have initiated and provided facilitation support at seminars, conferences<ref>{{cite web|url=http://traubman.igc.org/light2014.htm|title=Palestinian Jewish Dialogue Season of Light Three Continent Video Bridge – 2014|work=igc.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oneworldlights.net/news/archives/2154|title=OWL Global Wisdom Circle – 4/14/2015Listening to the Enemy|work=One World Lights}}</ref> and youth gatherings,<ref name="auto"/> created both printed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://traubman.igc.org/dialoguecommunication.htm|title=Dialogue communication graphics Arabic Hebrew French English listening peacebuilding reconciliation education|work=igc.org}}</ref> and video<ref name="auto1">{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/15811594|title=ABRAHAM'S VISION Graduation Day! – Muslim & Jewish youth learning together – 2010 (40 min)|work=Vimeo}}</ref> facilitation guidelines, and responded to requests for media interviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ac360.blogs.cnn.com/2008/10/16/palestinians-jews-engaging-and-creating/|title=Palestinians, Jews engaging and creating|work=cnn.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kalw.org/term/jewish-palestinian-dialogue|title=Jewish-Palestinian Dialogue|work=kalw.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://icermediation.com/2013/09/28/the-citizen-to-citizen-public-peace-process-icerm-radio-program-with-libby-and-len-traubman/|title=The Citizen-To-Citizen Public Peace Process – ICERM Radio Program with Libby and Len Traubman – International Center for Ethno-Religious Mediation|work=International Center for Ethno-Religious Mediation}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/128067221|title=Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue – Archival TV news (April 2002 – 10 min)|work=Vimeo}}</ref> Interest in their work increased in national media during the 2000 [[Second Intifada|Intifada]].<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/128069808|title=Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue – Archival TV news (October 2000 – 4 min)|work=Vimeo}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/128078593|title=Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue – Archival local ABC news (October 2000 – 3 min)|work=Vimeo}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/128079853|title=Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue – Archival local NBC news (October 2000 – 3 min)|work=Vimeo}}</ref> The group co-founders gave the 2017 Commencement Address at Notre Dame de Namur University,<ref>[[Notre Dame de Namur University]]</ref> <ref>http://www.ndnu.edu/media-center/libby-and-len-traubman-commencement-2017/</ref>"STORIES OF CHANGE: Creating a Culture of Connection in The Citizens’ Century".<ref>http://traubman.igc.org/ndnu2017address.pdf</ref>
==Beginnings== Initial incentive to form the dialogue group came from [[Peaceful coexistence|coexistence]] models of the 1980s in the Middle East and Africa. Examples are: [[Neve Shalom| Neve Shalom ~ Wahat as-Salam]] (Oasis of Peace), a village where Jewish and Palestinian Israeli families live and learn together, and Koinonia Southern Africa,<ref name="OPLNF">Dale Martin, "Old-fashioned Potlucks Lead to New Friendships", The Times, San Mateo, California, March 29, 1991, [http://traubman.igc.org/koinonia.htm Mirror of article]</ref><ref>Libby and Len Traubman, Remembering our roots in Koinonia Southern Africa, [http://traubman.igc.org/koinoniastory.htm Website article]</ref> founded by [[Nico Smith|Reverend Nico Smith]] during [[Apartheid in South Africa|apartheid]] years, which gathered thousands of Blacks and Whites together to share meals and stories, sometimes in public at risk to their lives. Both initiatives were honored together during the San Francisco 1989 [[Beyond War]] Award Ceremony.<ref name="BWAC1989-Video">Beyond War Award – 1989 – Neve Shalom~Wahat al-Salam – Carter Center – Koinonia Southern Africa [https://archive.org/details/BeyondWarAward-1989-NeveShalomwahatAl-salamTheCarterCenter Free Video]</ref> The word [[Koinonia]] means "belonging together" or "communion by intimate participation"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ancientroadpublications.com/Studies/BiblicalStudies/FellowshipintheGospel.html|title="Fellowship in the Gospel" : A Study of the Greek Word Koinonia|work=ancientroadpublications.com}}</ref>
Several members of this dialogue group have deep roots in the principles and educational tradition of the [[Beyond War]] movement of the 1980s, which was succeeded by the Foundation for Global Community, the group's first fiscal sponsor.<ref>http://globalcommunity.org/fgcHistory.pdf</ref> Fiscal oversight support was later provided by the [[Peninsula Conflict Resolution Center]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcrcweb.org/people/|title=Community Partners – Peninsula Conflict Resolution Center|work=pcrcweb.org}}</ref>
In 1991, several of the dialogue group founders, who had worked with the [[Beyond War|Beyond War Foundation]] and the Stanford Center on Conflict and Negotiation, brought together Palestinian and Israeli citizen leaders who forged and signed the '' "Framework for a Public Peace Process" ''.<ref name="FWPPP">Stanford Center on International Conflict and Negotiation, [[Beyond War|Beyond War Foundation]], ''FRAMEWORK FOR A PUBLIC PEACE PROCESS: Toward a Peaceful Israeli-Palestinian Relationship'', 1991. [http://traubman.igc.org/ppp.pdf PDF]</ref>
==The Living Room Dialogue model==
[[Image:LivingRoomDialogueGroup.jpg|300px|right|thumbnail|Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue Group]] Engaging in [[peacebuilding]], the early [[Muslim]], [[Jewish]], and [[Christian]] women and men participants in the dialogue group were determined to export solutions, rather than import problems. They intended to create a people-intensive—not money-intensive—easily reproducible, in-home model to parallel and compliment the government [[Peace process in the Israeli–Palestinian conflict|peace process in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict]] as well as in other regions of the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newerasupportfoundation.org/exploring-faiths|title=New Era Educational and Charitable Support Foundation – Exploring Faiths|work=New Era Educational and Charitable Support Foundation}}</ref> By 1993, government negotiators were clarifying their own plea for mandatory citizen participation and the need for the creativity of People-to-People Programs, as found in Annex VI of the 1993 Oslo Accords.<ref name="GuideToPeaceProcess">THE ISRAELI-PALESTINIAN INTERIM AGREEMENT ON THE WEST BANK AND THE GAZA STRIP, Annex VI, Protocol Concerning Israeli-Palestinian Cooperation Programs, 1999, [http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Peace+Process/Guide+to+the+Peace+Process/THE+ISRAELI-PALESTINIAN+INTERIM+AGREEMENT+-+Annex+VI.htm Website Page]</ref>
As designed, the living room dialogue group format gives dynamic form to the emerging paradigm of people-centered [[human security]] that challenges traditional notions of government-centered [[national security]] and is focused on sustained state, regional, and global stability.
==Means of change== Change is viewed by the dialogue group in [[Binary number|binary]] terms—a "no" component and a "yes" component. While defining the "no" component—what is wrong, disintegrating, and in need of correction—the dialogue's larger intention is to embody and paint a picture of the "yes," The intent is to focus less on the old and the obsolete—what does not work—and more on modeling the new, the "yes" component that works for the good of all. The dialogue group's ongoing experience is that change begins in small circles of local innovators and [[Cultural creatives|Culture Creatives]].
The means of [[Communication]] to strengthen relationships, release creativity, and effect change is [[Dialogue]], with its quality of [[Listening]] for [[Learning]]. While the action of dialogue is designed to deepen and enhance circles of relationships, it is not to be mistaken for safe, casual [[Conversation]] or adversarial, win-lose Debate. Furthermore, this type of dialogue's contribution to [[Conflict transformation|Conflict Transformation]] is not in [[Conflict resolution|Conflict Resolution]] or [[Deliberation]]. Rather this type of dialogue is used to introduce, familiarize, humanize, dignify, and empathize with all the people in the room, so that [[Conflict resolution|Conflict Resolution]] and [[Deliberation]] can then take place on a solid foundation. In particular, the dialogue process begins with exploring each person's life [[narrative]], because in many cases "an enemy is one whose story we have not heard". A beneficial outcome of this type of dialogue is a reduction in the widespread humiliation and [[rankism]] on Earth as defined by [[Robert W. Fuller]].
This [[Track II diplomacy|Track II Diplomacy]] approach is not a quick fix but requires time, and thus is rightfully referred to as Sustained Dialogue,<ref> https://sustaineddialogue.org/our-approach/</ref> as defined by [[Harold H. Saunders|Dr. Harold H. (Hal) Saunders]]. Useful practices of this [[cross-cultural communication]] continue to improve, drawing from the best of [[Bohm Dialogue]], [[Interfaith dialogue|Interfaith Dialogue]], and the ongoing global [[Dialogue Among Civilizations]].
==Activities== The contributions made by this dialogue group to the expanding effort to choose conversation over conflict were recognized in the Directory of Arab/Jewish/Palestinian Dialogue Groups published by the Center for Restorative Justice and Peacemaking at the University of Minnesota.<ref>http://www.cehd.umn.edu/ssw/RJP/Projects/Palestinian-Israeli-Connection/Directory_Arab_Jewish_Palestinian_Dialogue_Groups.pdf</ref> Always seeking to expand the network, participants in this Dialogue Group communicate daily face-to-face and by e-mail, [[telephone]], and [[Skype]] with citizens worldwide to encourage new groups and provide both graphic and written how-to guidelines (pdf).<ref>{{cite web|title=how-to guidelines|url=http://traubman.igc.org/changechartsall.pdf}}</ref> This dialogue group regularly publishes e-mail reports on the global success stories regarding the expanding public peace process.<ref>What Others Are Doing: E-mail Reports About Successful Palestinian-Jewish and Interfaith Relationship Building Activities [http://traubman.igc.org/messages.htm Website Page]</ref>
===Creating and Distributing Educational Tools and Instruction Guides=== The dialogue method draws on the wisdom of [[Elie Wiesel]]: "People become the stories they hear and the stories they tell." Dialogue-initiated [[peacebuilding]] successes are documented in film and other tools of [[education]] that are available for [[community building]]. Documents created by the group and freely distributed for use by others include: Palestinian & Jewish Recipes for Peace,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://traubman.igc.org/recipes.htm|title=Palestinian & Jewish Recipes for Peace – Middle East Israeli Arabic Food Cookbook Holiday Gift|work=igc.org}}</ref> Camp Activities for Relationship Building (pdf),<ref>{{cite web|title=Camp Activities for Relationship Building|url=http://traubman.igc.org/campacts.pdf}}</ref> The Public Peace Process of Change (pdf),<ref>{{cite web|title=The Public Peace Process of Change|url=http://traubman.igc.org/changechartsall.pdf}}</ref> MEETING MOHAMMED: Beginning Jewish-Palestinian Dialogue (pdf),<ref>{{cite web|title=MEETING MOHAMMED: Beginning Jewish-Palestinian Dialogue|url=http://traubman.igc.org/MeetingMohammedEng.pdf}}</ref> STORY AS ENTRY TO RELATIONSHIP: Teacher's Guide (pdf),<ref>{{cite web|title=STORY AS ENTRY TO RELATIONSHIP: Teacher's Guide|url=http://traubman.igc.org/vidschoolguide.pdf}}</ref> ENGAGING THE OTHER: Teacher's Guide (pdf)<ref>{{cite web|title=ENGAGING THE OTHER: Teacher's Guide|url=http://traubman.igc.org/engagingtheother.pdf}}</ref> and also see related Theses and documents of others.<ref>{{cite web|title=related theses and documents of others|url=http://traubman.igc.org/theses.htm}}</ref> The dialogue also maintains a web resource page referencing multi-lingual graphics that can be used by other groups wanting to use dialogue as a communication tool.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masterpeace.org/blogs/post/useful_graphics_on_change_communication_and_relationships_of_peacebuilding|title=USEFUL MULTI-LINGUAL GRAPHICS for Change, Communication, and Relationships of Peacebuilding|work=masterpeace.org}}</ref>

[[Image:PeaceMakersCamp.JPG|300px|right|thumb|Palestinian-Jewish Family Peacemakers Camp]]
:'''Palestinian-Jewish Family Peacemakers Cam'''p :From 2003–2007, the dialogue group partnered with [[Camp Tawonga]] to bring hundreds of Muslim, Jewish and Christian, elders, adults, and youth from 50 different towns in [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] and [[Israel]] to successfully live together and communicate with each other at the Palestinian-Jewish Family Peacemakers Camp—Oseh Shalom – Sanea al-Salam.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/education/article/jews_and_palestinians_talk_peace_under_norcal_pines_20071102|title=Jews and Palestinians talk peace under NorCal pines – Education|work=Jewish Journal}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/TUOLUMNE-COUNTY-Peaceful-setting-intense-2470022.php|title=TUOLUMNE COUNTY / Peaceful setting, intense dialogue|work=SFGate}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6j8ANQhpelI|title=Peacemakers Camp News – 2005|date=April 15, 2010|work=YouTube}}</ref><ref>http://traubman.igc.org/camp2006radio.mp3</ref>
:Participants included former armed combatants from both sides of the conflict. The attendees worked together to transcend stereotypes in an effort to dignify one another and demonstrate what peaceful, face to face coexistence looks like. Participants returned to the Middle East to begin or expand their own successful relationship-building initiatives including: Arava Institute for Environmental Studies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arava.org/|title=Arava Institute for Environmental Studies – The premier environmental studies and research program in the Middle East|work=arava.org}}</ref> Givat Haviva,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.givathaviva.org/|title=Givat Haviva – The Center for a Shared Society|author=Simply-Smart|work=givathaviva.org}}</ref> Interfaith Encounter Association,<ref>http://interfaith-encounter.org/</ref> Combatants for Peace,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cfpeace.org/|title=Combatants For Peace|work=cfpeace.org}}</ref> Neve Shalom~Wahat al-Salam,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nswas.com/|title=Oasis of Peace|work=Oasis of Peace}}</ref> Nir School of the Heart,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nirschool.org/|title=Welcome to NIR School|work=nirschool.org}}</ref> Peace Child Israel, and<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mideastweb.org/peacechild/|title=Peacechild Israel|work=mideastweb.org}}</ref> Sulha Peace Project.<ref>Sulha Peace Project</ref>
== Documentary filmography == [[Image:PeacemakersFilm.jpg|250px|right|thumbnail|PEACEMAKERS: Palestinians & Jews Together at Camp (2007)]] A variety of films document The Dialogue Group's domestic and international experiences. Over 13,000 DVDs have been requested from all continents and every U.S. state including citizens from 2,594 institutions, 2,601 cities, in 82 nations including 20 countries in Africa. Films include:
* '''PEACEMAKERS''': Palestinians & Jews Together at Camp<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NJ28TNR19Q0|title=Peacemakers – Palestinians & Jews Together at Camp|date=October 20, 2009|work=YouTube}}</ref> * '''DIALOGUE AT WASHINGTON HIGH'''<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scF3I6NhpRI|title=Dialogue at Washington High|date=October 21, 2009|work=YouTube}}</ref> Tenth grade students follow the example of a Palestinian and a Jew to make new connections. * '''CROSSING LINES IN FRESNO'''<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/10163892|title=CROSSING LINES IN FRESNO (documentary – 29 min)|work=Vimeo}}</ref> In 2009, eighty diverse youth and adults engaged in authentic Dialogue with a new quality of listening to learn. Face to face, they experienced that "an enemy is one whose story we have not heard." This Fresno, California public evening can be replicated anywhere on Earth, as a first step to building community. * '''DIALOGUE IN NIGERIA: Muslims & Christians Creating Their Future'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newerasupportfoundation.org/exploring-faiths|title=New Era Educational and Charitable Support Foundation – "DIALOGUE IN NIGERIA: Muslims & Christians Creating Their Future"|work=New Era Educational and Charitable Support Foundation}}</ref> This award-winning film, documented the 2010 2nd International Conference on Youth and Interfaith Communication in Jos, Nigeria. The film and the conference for 200 diverse African women and men resulted from international collaboration between the New Era Educational and Charitable Support Foundation and the Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue Group, California, USA. In addition, support from and participation by members of the dialogue group in this effort to dignify and integrate Albinos into the national community can be seen on the banner in the background of the two and one half minute Dote d'Ivoire national newscast.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/100366261|title=Albino ~ Non-Albino Reconciliation – April 2014 – Bouake, Cote d'Ivoire (with English sub-titles)|work=Vimeo}}</ref> * '''20 YEARS OF PALESTINIAN-JEWISH LIVING ROOM DIALOGUE (1992–2012)'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/20YearsOfPalestinian-jewishLivingRoomDialogue|title=20 Years of Palestinian-Jewish Living Room Dialogue|work=Internet Archive}}</ref> This 2012 48-minute, grassroots film archives the 20-year history of the Jewish-Palestinian Living Room Dialogue on the San Francisco Peninsula of northern California, USA. It documents its historic roots in the 1980s, step-by-step beginnings from 1992, projects and progress, both national and international, initiated and guided by a local handful of Muslim, Christian, and Jewish women, men, and youth. * '''ABRAHAM'S VISION: Graduation Day!'''<ref name="auto1"/> On Sunday June 13, 2010, The University of San Francisco hosted Muslim and Jewish high school students graduating from the year-long Unity Program of Abraham's Vision. Thirty-nine teens had successfully learned about Muslims, Jews, Islam, and Judaism, while strengthening relationships among themselves and with their own communities and religious traditions.

[[File:Karl Ludwig Sand.png|thumb|Karl Ludwig Sand]] '''Karl Ludwig Sand''' ([[Wunsiedel]], [[Upper Franconia]] (then in [[Prussia]]), 5 October 1795 – [[Mannheim]], 20 May 1820) was a [[Germany|German]] university student and member of a liberal [[Burschenschaft]] (student association). He was executed in 1820 for the murder of the [[Conservatism|conservative]] dramatist [[August von Kotzebue]] the previous year in [[Mannheim]]. As a result of his execution, Sand became a martyr in the eyes of many German nationalists seeking the creation of a united German national state.
==Biography== Karl Ludwig Sand was born to Gottfried Christoph Sand and his wife Dorothea Johanna Wilhelmina Schöpf (1766–1826), on 5 October 1795. His siblings were George, Fritz, Caroline and Julia.
===Education=== [[File:Wartburg-Studentenzug-1817.jpg|thumb|Students marching towards the Wartburg, of which Sand was one.]] In 1804 he attended the ''Lateinschule'' (Latin school) in [[Wunsiedel]] and in 1810 he moved on to the grammar school (''Gymnasium'') in [[Hof, Germany|Hof]], living with the school's rector, [[Georg Heinrich Saalfrank]], a friend of Sand's Enlightened Protestant family. Following the closure of the Hof Gymnasium on the institution of [[Montgelas]]'s Reforms, Sand followed his teacher to the Neues Gymnasium (New Grammar School) in [[Regensburg]], completing his studies in September 1814. In November 1814 Sand matriculated at the [[Eberhard Karls University of Tübingen|University of Tübingen]].
In 1815, Sand volunteered under Major von Falkenhausen, participating in the [[Battle of Waterloo]] in June and in Paris by July. He returned from the war disillusioned with its results and fell into a deep depression. In 1816, while at the [[University of Erlangen]], Sand formed Burschenschaft Teutonia with his friend Dittmar, meeting at castle ruins near Erlangen which they had named Ruttli. They built a meeting house for their group of 80 students. Sand's depression was further intensified by the destruction of Ruttli by the competing political group the Landmannschaft and the drowning death of Dittmar in 1817. Starting in 1817 he studied at the [[University of Jena]], attending the lectures of [[Jakob Friedrich Fries]], [[Heinrich Luden]] and [[Lorenz Oken]] and joining further Burschenschaften. Sand was among the nationalist students who gathered at the 1817 [[Wartburg festival]], in which Kotzebue's ''History of the German Empires'' was one of the [[book burning|books ceremoniously burned]].
===Murder of August von Kotzebue=== [[File:Ermordung August von Kotzebues.jpg|thumb|Illustration of Sand's attack on Kotzebue.]] Sand already contemplated the murder of [[August von Kotzebue]] in a diary entry of 5 May 1818. He called him a "traitor to the nation" and a "deceiver of the people" and characterized him as an enemy of the Burschenschaft.
On the morning of 23 March 1819 Sand, using the pseudonym Henry, visited Kotzebue in his Mannheim house. Refused entry to the house and told to return in the afternoon, Sand returned just before five o'clock. Having exchanged just a few words with Kotzebue, Sand produced a dagger and, with the words "Here, you traitor to the fatherland!", stabbed him repeatedly in the chest. Surprised by Kotzebue's four-year-old son witnessing the event from the nursery, Sand lost his wits and stabbed himself. Leaving the house, he handed a servant a piece of writing he had prepared ''("Death to August von Kotzebue")'', and stabbed himself again in the street. His suicide attempt failed, and he was taken to hospital.
==Aftermath== The Mannheim ''Hofgericht'' (court of law) sentenced Sand to death on 5 May 1820. He was [[beheading|beheaded]] by [[Franz Wilhelm Widmann]], who was the [[executioner|official executioner]] at the time. [[File:Sands Hinrichtung.png|thumb|The execution of Karl Ludwig Sand.]] [[File:Klsand-Grab.JPG|thumb|200px|His grave in Mannheim]] Sand's murder of Kotzebue was a catalyst for government restrictions on liberal and German nationalist thought. On 20 September 1819 [[Prince Klemens Wenzel von Metternich]] called a meeting of representatives from across the [[German Confederation]] to create the [[Carlsbad Decrees]] which outlawed the Burschenschaften and put limits on freedom of the press and the rights of members of such organizations, banning them from public office, teaching or studying at universities.<ref name=Carlsbad>[http://www.milestonedocuments.com/documents/full-text/carlsbad-decrees Full text of Carlsbad Decrees]</ref>
[[Alexandre Dumas, père]] wrote about Sand's life and published excerpts from his journals and letters in ''Karl Ludwig Sand'',<ref name=Dumas>[http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/2745 ''Karl Ludwig Sand''] by Alexandre Dumas, père</ref> part of ''Celebrated Crimes''.<ref name=Crimecelebre>[http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/2760 ''Celebrated Crimes''], Alexandre Dumas, père</ref> Prior to writing his story, Dumas visited Widmann's son in [[Mannheim]] in 1838 to gather information about Sand's character. [[Alexander Pushkin]] also memorialized Sand in his poem about assassins entitled "Kinzhal" (The Dagger).<ref name=Terras>Terras, Victor, ''Handbook of Russian literature By Victor Terras'' page 96</ref> In Germany three films have been made concerning the events of Karl Sand's life: ''Karl Sand'' in 1964, ''Sand'' in 1971, and ''Die Unbedingten'' in 2009.
==Writings== * ''Gründung einer allgemeinen freien Burschenschaft'', 1817 * ''Teutsche Jugend an die teutsche Menge, zum 18. October 1818'' * ''Todesstoß dem August von Kotzebue'', 1818/19, published posthumously.

Universitätsverlag Winter, Heidelberg 2005. Beigefügt: ''Acten-Auszüge aus dem Untersuchungs-Process über Carl Ludwig Sand.'' Nachdr. der 2. Aufl. Mannheim 1819 sowie Altenburg 1821. {{ISBN|3-8253-2005-7}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2018}} {{multiple issues| {{one source|date=July 2012}} {{advert|date=June 2012}} {{cleanup-reorganize|date=June 2012}} }} '''The Karnataka Quiz Association''' (or KQA) was founded in 1983 by the late Wing Commander G.R.Mulky, Deepak Murdeshwar, Rajeev Gowda, Thomas Uthup, K.N.Mahabala, Thribhuvan Kumar, P.Raju and Jagadish Raja{{cite web|url=http://kqaquizzes.org/about/|title=About KQA|work=Karnataka Quiz Association|accessdate=2011-11-01}} is a non-profit association devoted to popularizing the mindsport among students and the general public in Bangalore and beyond. Contests are held regularly in the following categories: Middle School, High School, Junior College, College, and Open-to-all. In addition, specialist quizzes in the areas of Literature, Entertainment, Music, Art, Comics and Business are held every year. The KQA holds events in [[English language|English]] and [[Kannada]]. Apart from holding contests, the KQA also conducts workshops in quizzing for school students and provides quizmasters for events held by other organisations. The KQA has an informal membership policy. People interested in quizzing sign up to receive a free email newsletter about forthcoming contests. The newsletter goes out to about 2000 people at present. KQA quizzes normally used to take place once every month at the [[Daly Memorial Hall]], a charming British-era building on Nrupatunga Road. Now, however the venue has shifted to Arakere Hall(also known as the IAT Hall) on Queen's Road. KQA's flagship event, [[ASKQANCE]], is held in the third week of June every year and comprises three quizzes, one each in the School, Corporate and Open Categories. The KQA also holds a solo quiz titled [[Mahaquizzer]] as well as a solo quiz event called MindSweep across India's several quizzing cities annually. Since 2003, the KQA has collaborated with the TI Foundation in conducting the [[Jack Kilby Quiz]] in Science and Technology for high school students. == ASKQANCE == The quizzing season in Bangalore has always begun with an open quiz in June to mark the anniversary of the founding of the KQA. This tradition was reworked around the time of the 20th anniversary in 2003 to include a School Quiz, a Corporate Quiz and the customary Open Quiz. This festival of quizzing was christened ASKQANCE to celebrate the ethic of thinking laterally and working things out. ASKQANCE draws teams from other quizzing centres such as Chennai, Hyderabad, Cochin, New Delhi and Pune. == The Texas Instruments Science and Technology Quiz == The TI Foundation has conducted a quiz in science and technology for school students since 2003 in collaboration with the KQA. The quiz was originally named after Nobel laureate [[Jack Kilby]] who designed the first [[Integrated Circuit]] while working for [[Texas Instruments]] but is now known by the name of the company. The first three editions of the quiz, hosted by Ochintya Sharma, were held in Bangalore, and attracted participation from more than 200 schools in the region. The quiz went national in 2006, with winners from Bangalore, Chennai and New Delhi facing off at a grand finale in Delhi.In the year 2008, the contest was extended to two more cities - Pune and Kolkata. == Texas Instruments Science & Technology Quiz winners == '''2003: National Public School (Indiranagar)''' '''2004: Delhi Public School, Bangalore''' '''2005: Sri Kumaran Children's Home''' 2006: Bangalore Winners—National Public School (Indiranagar)
2006: Chennai Winners—SRDF Vivekananda Vidyalaya
2006: New Delhi Winners—DPS RK Puram '''2006: National Winners—National Public School (Indiranagar)''' 2007: New Delhi Winners—Bluebell
2007: Chennai Winners—Vidya Mandir, Mylapore
2007: Bangalore Winners—Sri Kumaran Children's Home '''2007: National Winners—Vidya Mandir, Mylapore, Chennai''' 2008: Bangalore Winners—National Public School, Indiranagar
2008: Delhi Winners—Delhi Public School, RK Puram
2008: Pune Winners—Vikhe Patil School
2008: Kolkata Winners—Don Bosco Kolkata
2008: Chennai Winners—Padma Sheshadri Bal Bhavan, Chennai '''2008: National Winners—Padma Sheshadri Bal Bhavan, Chennai''' 2009: Kolkata Winners—Birla High School
2009: New Delhi Winners—Delhi Public School, Ghaziabad
2009: Chennai Winners—PSBB Sr Secondary School, Nungambakkam
2009: Pune Winners—Abhinava Vidyalaya English Medium High School
2009: Bangalore Winners—Sri Kumaran Public School (ICSE) '''2009: National Winners—Sri Kumaran Public School (ICSE) - Bangalore ''' '''2010: National Winners—Sri Kumaran Public School (ICSE) - Bangalore ''' 2011: Kolkata Winners—Nalanda Talent School, VIZAG
2011: New Delhi Winners—Amity International School, SAKET
2011: Chennai Winners—Sri Sankara Sr Sec School, Adyar
2011: Mumbai Winners—St. Augustine's High School
2011: Bangalore Winners—Sri Vidya Mandir High School '''2011: National Winners—Nalanda Talent School, VIZAG ''' 2013: Kolkata Winners—Don Bosco
2013: New Delhi Winners—Amity International School, SAKET
2013: Chennai Winners—P S Senior Secondary School
2013: Mumbai Winners—St. Augustine's High School
2013: Bangalore Winners—Sri Kumaran Children's Home(CBSE) '''2013: National Winners—Sri Kumaran Children's Home(CBSE) ''' == MahaQuizzer == [[Mahaquizzer]] was begun in 2005 as an attempt to popularise KQA-style quizzing in other parts of the country. The quiz is a solo championship requiring contestants to try out 150 questions over 90 minutes on the same day at different venues across the country. The first edition of the quiz was held in Bangalore, Chennai, Hyderabad, Thiruvananthapuram and Mumbai. The quiz was extended to New Delhi, Pune and Kolkata in 2006 while Bhubaneshwar became a venue in 2007. Winners are declared for each city and the overall winner is awarded the [[MahaQuizzer]] title for that year. Since 2006, the Wing Commander G.R. Mulky Memorial Trophy for Quizzing Excellence has been awarded to the overall winner each year. == MahaQuizzer winners == 2005: Anustup Datta
2006: Swaminathan G.
2007: Samanth Subramanian
2008: Arul Mani
2009: Anustup Datta
2010: Shouvik Guha
2011: Arul Mani{{cite web|url=http://kqaquizzes.org/2011/06/10/mahaquizzer-2011-top-100-and-international-results/|title=Mahaquizzer 2011 Top 100 and International results|date=9 June 2011|website=kqaquizzes.org}}

2013: Anustup Datta{{cite web|url=http://kqaquizzes.org/2013/06/09/mahaquizzer-2013-top-100-scores/|title=Mahaquizzer 2013 – Top 100 Scores|date=9 June 2013|website=kqaquizzes.org}}

2014: Vinoo Sanjay{{cite web|url=http://kqaquizzes.org/2014/12/28/mahaquizzer-2014-scores-and-ranks/|title=Mahaquizzer 2014 – Scores and Ranks|date=27 December 2014|website=kqaquizzes.org}}

2017: Rahul Kottalgi, Vinoo Sanjay{{cite web|url=http://kqaquizzes.org/2018/01/10/mahaquizzer-2017-rankings/|title=MahaQuizzer 2017 – Rankings|date=9 January 2018|website=kqaquizzes.org}}
* A one-off KQA 30th Anniversary Special edition of Mahaquizzer was held == Go Ogle == KQA also holds an online solo quiz championship titled Go Ogle on New Year's Day. The quiz attracts participants from a small band of diehard quizzers across the world. == Go Ogle winners == 2006: Anustup Datta, Bangalore
2007: Siddhartha Sen, Bangalore
2008: Kiran Vijayakumar, Chennai
2009: Jayakanthan, Chennai
2010: Arun Hiregange, Bangalore
2011: Thejaswi Udupa, Bangalore == Mega-Whats == Mega-Whats is the National Open Quizzing Championship, begun in 2009. The contest is held simultaneously in several Indian cities on the second Sunday in December every year. Winners from these cities then meet each other for the Mega-Whats Face-off the following June during the KQA Anniversary. == Mega-Whats City Winners 2009 == Bangalore: We Are Like This Wonly, 61

'''Mega-Whats Face-off Winners 2010-11—Insignificant Others, Chennai ''' == See also == * [[Quizzing in India]] * [[Mahaquizzer]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{Official website|http://kqaquizzes.org}} * [http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/article2596104.ece Article by Harshini Vakkalanka in The Hindu, 2011] * [http://hindu.com/thehindu/mag/2003/08/17/stories/2003081700110300.htm Article by Sevanti Ninan in The Hindu, 2003] {{Bangalore topics}} [[Category:Student quiz competitions]] [[Category:Organisations based in Bangalore]] [[Category:Competitions in India]] [[Category:1983 establishments in India]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1983]]

{{Infobox project | hi = <!-- Alternatively, use native_name --> | logo = | image = | caption = | mission_statement = | type = | country = India | primeminister = | key_people = | launched = July 2004<!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | disestablished = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | budget = | current_status = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} The '''Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya''' or '''KGBV''' is a residential girls’ [[secondary school]] run by [[Government of India]] for the weaker sections in India
==History== It was a scheme was introduced by the [[Government of India]] in August 2004, then integrated in the [[Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan]] program, to provide educational facilities for girls belonging to [[Scheduled Castes]], [[Scheduled Tribes]], [[Other Backward Class]]es, minority communities and families below the [[poverty line]] in Educationally Backward Blocks.<ref name=indg>[http://www.indg.in/primary-education/women-and-education/guidelines-for-implementation-of-kasturba-gandhi-balika-vidyalaya/ Revised Guidelines for Implementation of Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya (KGBVs)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419180758/http://www.indg.in/primary-education/women-and-education/guidelines-for-implementation-of-kasturba-gandhi-balika-vidyalaya |date=2012-04-19 }}</ref>
==Objective== Gender disparities still persist in rural areas and among disadvantaged communities. Looking at enrolment trends, there remain significant gaps in the enrollment of girls at the elementary level as compared to boys, especially at the upper primary levels. The objective of KGBV is to ensure that quality education is feasible and accessible to the girls of disadvantaged groups of society by setting up residential schools with boarding facilities at elementary level.<ref name=indg />
==Eligibility== The scheme was applicable since inception in 2004, in Educationally Backward Blocks (EBBs) where the rural female literacy is below the national average (46.13%: Census 2001) and gender gap in literacy is more than the national average (21.59%: Census 2001). Among these blocks, schools may be set up in areas with: # concentration of tribal population, with low female literacy and/or a large number of girls out of school; # concentration of SC, OBC and minority populations, with low female literacy and/or a large number of girls out of school; # areas with low female literacy; or # areas with a large number of small, scattered habitations that do not qualify for a school
The criteria of eligible blocks has been revised with effect from 1 April 2008 to include the following: * An additional 316 Educationally backward blocks with rural female literacy below 30%; and * 94 Towns/cities having minority concentration (as per the list identified by Ministry of Minority Affairs) with female literacy rate below the national average (53.67%: Census 2001).
==Coverage== [[File:Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya nayagaon sonpur bihar.jpg|thumb|right|Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya, [[Nayagaon, Bihar]], sonpur]] The scheme has been implemented in 28 states and union territories: [[Assam]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[Telangana]], [[Arunachal Pradesh]], [[Bihar]], [[Chhattisgarh]], [[Dadra and Nagar Haveli]], [[Delhi]], [[Gujarat]], [[Haryana]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[Jammu and Kashmir]], [[Jharkhand]], [[Karnataka]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], [[Maharashtra]], [[Manipur]], [[Meghalaya]], [[Mizoram]], [[Nagaland]], [[Odisha]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Tamil Nadu]], [[Tripura]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Uttarakhand]] and [[West Bengal]].<ref>[http://ssa.nic.in/girls-education/kasturba-gandhi-balika-vidyalaya/kgbv-scheme/ Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidhayalaya (KGBV) Scheme detail]</ref>
2578 KGBVs were sanctioned by Government of India.<ref name=renamed_from_2_on_20170321214147>[http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/mbErel.aspx?relid=94614|date=April 2013]</ref> Of these, 427 KGBVs have been sanctioned in Muslim concentration blocks, 612 in ST blocks, 688 in SC blocks. A total of 750 residential schools would be opened in educational backward blocks. 75% entrollment is reserved for girls from SC, ST, OBC and Minority communities and the other 25% to girls from families below the poverty line.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://ssa.nic.in/girls-education/kasturba-gandhi-balika-vidyalaya Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya] * [http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/mbErel.aspx?relid=94614] {{Government Schemes in India}}

revision.text:
{{More footnotes|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox university | name = King Saud bin Abdulaziz University for Health Sciences | native_name = جامعة الملك سعود بن عبدالعزيز للعلوم الصحية | image_name = Ksau-hslogo.png | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = جامعة لصحة وطن | motto_lang = Arabic | mottoeng = A university for a nation's health. | established = 25 April 2005 | closed = | type = Public | affiliation = | endowment = | budget = | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chancellor = | president = Dr. Bandar Al Knawy | vice-president = Prof. Youssef Al Eissa, Prof. Mohamed Al Moamary, Dr. Abdulmajeed Al Abdulkareem. | superintendent = | provost = | vice_chancellor = | rector = | principal = | dean = Prof.Fayez Al-Hejaili,Prof. Ali Al-Tuwaijri,Dr. Khaled Al Jamaan,Dr. Mohammed Ghaihab Al Ghaihab,Dr. Sulaiman Abdullah Al Queflie | director = | head_label = | head = | academic_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = 3085 | undergrad = 2584 | postgrad = 501 | doctoral = | other = | city = [[Riyadh]], [[Jeddah]], and [[Al-Hasa|Al Ahsa]] | state = | province = | country = [[Saudi Arabia]] | coor = | campus = Multiple campuses | former_names = | free_label = | free = | colors = | colours = | athletics = | sports = | nickname = KSAU-HS| mascot = | affiliations = [[National Guard Health Affairs]] | website = [http://www.ksau-hs.edu.sa/ ksau-hs.edu.sa] | logo = | footnotes = }}
'''King Saud bin Abdulaziz University for Health Sciences''' (KSAU-HS) ([[Arabic]]: '''جامعة الملك سعود بن عبد العزيز للعلوم الصحية''') is the first public university in the [[Kingdom of Saudi Arabia]] and the Middle East region specialized in health sciences. Its headquarters is in the main campus in [[Riyadh]], the capital of [[Saudi Arabia]]. It has two other campuses both in [[Jeddah]] and [[Al-Hasa|Al-Ahsa]]. All of the campuses are located inside the parameters of [[King Abdulaziz Medical cities]], and are overseen by the Saudi [[National Guard Health Affairs]].
==History== The university was formally established in 2005 as a result of the positive feedback from the postgraduate programs in various medical fields that had been offered by the National Guard Health Affairs ([http://www.ngha.med.sa/English/Pages/default.aspx NGHA]) since the mid-1980s. The advanced medical facilities at the King Abdulaziz Medical Cities in Riyadh, Jeddah and Al-Ahsa proved to be critical foundations for the successful inception of the university.
KSAU-HS’s main campus is in Riyadh with two additional campuses in Jeddah and Al-Ahsa. The main campus in Riyadh hosts seven colleges: College of Medicine, College of Dentistry, College of Pharmacy, College of Public Health and Health Informatics, College of Applied Medial Sciences, College of Nursing and the College of Science & Health Professions. Jeddah Campus hosts College of Medicine, College of Nursing, College of Applied Medical Sciences and College of Sciences and Health Professions. Finally, Al-Ahsa Campus hosts College of Applied Medical Sciences, College of Nursing, and College of Sciences and Health Professions.
The umbrella of NGHA has given the KSAU-HS students access to King Abdulaziz Medical Cities in Riyadh, Jeddah and Al-Ahsa, which are considered to be the most advanced medical complexes in the region. Furthermore, it has enabled KSAU-HS to enhance its curricula and academic programs with clinical applications and training under health professionals.
==Campuses==
===Riyadh=== The campus is in the east of [[Riyadh]] and officially opened in April 2013.<ref name=trolleymotion2013>{{cite web|last=Lehmann|first=J.|title=Riad/Riyadh [SA] - Opening of the New Campus of the King Saud bin Abdulaziz University|url=https://old.trolleymotion.eu/index.php?id=38&L=3&n_ID=1783|date=6 May 2013|publisher=TrolleyMotion|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Its design is a mix of contemporary and Islamic architecture. The campus has a capacity of ten thousand students, but it can accommodate future increase in student enrolment.
There is a large landscaping area connecting the buildings with footpaths. In addition, there is a [[trolleybus]] line that connects the main areas of the campus with the housing compound.<ref name=trolleymotion2013/><ref name=trolleybusmagazine310>''Trolleybus Magazine'' No. 310 (July–August 2013), p. 110. UK: National Trolleybus Association. ISSN 0266-7452.</ref>
===Main Units on Campus=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Main Unit !! [[Riyadh]] !! [[Jeddah]] !! [[Al-Hasa|Al Ahsa]] !! web !! Dean |- | Administration Building || x|| x|| x |- | Conference Center || x|| x|| x |- | Clinical Skill Training Center || x|| x|| x |- | [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] International Medical Research Center || x|| x|| x |- | Deanship of Higher Education|| x|| -|| - |- | College of [[Medicine]]|| x|| x|| x|| [http://com.ksau-hs.edu.sa com] |- | College of [[Nursing]]|| x|| x|| x|| [http://nursing.ksau-hs.edu.sa nursing] |- | College of Dentistry || x|| -|| -|| [http://cod.ksau-hs.edu.sa cod] |- | College of Pharmacy|| x|| -|| -|| [http://cop.ksau-hs.edu.sa cop] |- | College of Science and Health Professions<ref>also named College of Basic Health Sciences</ref>|| x|| x|| x || [http://coshp.ksau-hs.edu.sa coshp] |- | College of Applied Medical Sciences|| x|| x|| x|| [http://cams.ksau-hs.edu.sa cams] |- | College of Public Health and Health Informatics|| x || -|| - || [https://ksau-hs.edu.sa/Arabic/colleges/cphhi/Pages/default.aspx cphhi] || [[Dr. Majed Alsalamah]] <ref>http://coshp.ksau-hs.edu.sa/DeansOfficce.aspx</ref> |- | Housing Compounds|| x|| x|| x |- | Sports Center|| x|| x|| x |- | Recreational Facilities || x|| x|| x |- | Year officially opened|| 2013 || 2015 || - |- | Students|| 10000|| 4000|| 3000 |}
==International collaboration==
KSAU-HS has a number of agreements and memoranda for [[academic collaboration]] with reputable [[North American]], [[Europe]]an, and [[Australian]] universities and institutions.
Memorandum of understanding with Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of [[Canada]], for the establishment of a Collaborating Center for [[CanMEDS]] competencies in Saudi Arabia. It will serve as the hub of a network of medical educators, trainers, and faculty committed to support, develop, and facilitate [[CanMEDS]] in all domain of medical education at both undergraduate, and postgraduate levels, as well as in the professional practice.
The center will host and present a series of conferences & workshops on residency training, and develop network of medical educators, and deliver education and training to the trainees in postgraduate medical education programs in [[Saudi Arabia]]. In Nov 2010, KSAU-HS hosted The Saudi Arabian Conference on Residency Education (SACRE). This conference was a landmark event that highlighted the collaboration KSAU-HS has with the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada. Topic discussed in the conference program included key trends in development of residency education, quality in residency program, contemporary and emerging tools for assessment of resident competence, simulation technology to teaching & learning in postgraduate medical education, teaching the domains of physician competence using the CanMEDS framework, best research in residency education, new approaches for enhancing excellence in teaching and assessment in residency, current controversies in residency education and the implications for their own program.
[[The Association for Medical Education in the Eastern Mediterranean Region]] (AMEEMR) selected King Saud bin Abdulaziz University to be its headquarters. This decision came at the Association’s 2010 General Assembly, which College of Medicine at KSAU-HS hosted. Twenty-three representatives from fifteen countries and a representative for President of [[World Federation for Medical Education]] (WFME) attended the meeting.
KSAU-HS has a number of licensing agreements to develop its academic programs with prestigious universities worldwide: [[University of Sydney]] (Australia); [[University of Liverpool]] (UK); [[South Alabama University]] (USA); [[Flinders University]] (Australia); [[University of Arkansas]] (USA), [[Thomas Jefferson University]] (USA) [[University of Maryland]] (USA), [[Maastricht University]] (Netherlands), The [[University of Oklahoma]] (USA) and the [[University of Tennessee Health Science Center]] (USA).
==See also== * [[National Guard Health Affairs]] * ''[[King Abdulllah Abdul Aziz Health Encyclopedia]]''
==References== {{Reflist}} * http://www.emro.who.int/hped/Countries.asp
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.ksau-hs.edu.sa}} * {{Official website|http://www.ksau-hs.edu.sa/English/Pages/Default.aspx}} (English)
